MemberSignature.Value: public static UnitsNet.Pressure CalculateBarometricPressure (UnitsNet.Pressure measuredPressure, UnitsNet.Temperature measuredTemperature, UnitsNet.Length measurementAltitude);

.method public static hidebysig valuetype UnitsNet.Pressure CalculateBarometricPressure(valuetype UnitsNet.Pressure measuredPressure, valuetype UnitsNet.Temperature measuredTemperature, valuetype UnitsNet.Length measurementAltitude) cil managed
Public Shared Function CalculateBarometricPressure (measuredPressure As Pressure, measuredTemperature As Temperature, measurementAltitude As Length) As Pressure
static member CalculateBarometricPressure : UnitsNet.Pressure * UnitsNet.Temperature * UnitsNet.Length -> UnitsNet.Pressure

Docs.param: Measured pressure at the observation point
Measured temperature at the observation point

Height over sea level of the observation point (to be really precise, geopotential heights have to be used above ~750m). Do not use the height obtained by calling or any of its overloads, since what would use redundant data.
Docs.summary:
Calculates the barometric pressure from a raw reading, using the reduction formula from the german met service. This is a more complex variant of . It gives the value that a weather station gives for a particular area and is also used in meteorological charts.
You are at 650m over sea and measure a pressure of 948.7 hPa and a temperature of 24.0°C. The met service will show that you are within a high-pressure area of around 1020 hPa.
Docs.returns: The barometric pressure at the point of observation

Docs.param: Measured pressure at the observation point
Measured temperature at the observation point
Height over sea level of the observation point (to be really precise, geopotential heights have to be used above ~750m)
Relative humidity at point of measurement
Docs.summary: Calculates the barometric pressure from a raw reading, using the reduction formula from the german met service. This is a more complex variant of . It gives the value that a weather station gives for a particular area and is also used in meteorological charts. Use this method if you also have the relative humidity.
Docs.returns: The barometric pressure at the point of observation

Docs.param: Measured pressure at the observation point
Measured temperature at the observation point
Vapor pressure, meteorologic definition
Height over sea level of the observation point (to be really precise, geopotential heights have to be used above ~750m)
Docs.summary:
Calculates the barometric pressure from a raw reading, using the reduction formula from the german met service. This is a more complex variant of . It gives the value that a weather station gives for a particular area and is also used in meteorological charts.
You are at 650m over sea and measure a pressure of 948.7 hPa and a temperature of 24.0°C. The met service will show that you are within a high-pressure area of around 1020 hPa.
Docs.returns: The barometric pressure at the point of observation

MemberSignature.Value: public static UnitsNet.Temperature CalculateHeatIndex (UnitsNet.Temperature airTemperature, UnitsNet.Ratio relativeHumidity);
.method public static hidebysig valuetype UnitsNet.Temperature CalculateHeatIndex(valuetype UnitsNet.Temperature airTemperature, valuetype UnitsNet.Ratio relativeHumidity) cil managed
Public Shared Function CalculateHeatIndex (airTemperature As Temperature, relativeHumidity As Ratio) As Temperature
static member CalculateHeatIndex : UnitsNet.Temperature * UnitsNet.Ratio -> UnitsNet.Temperature

Docs.param: The dry air temperature
The relative humidity (RH) expressed as a ratio
Docs.summary: The heat index (or apparent temperature) is used to measure the amount of discomfort during the summer months when heat and humidity often combine to make it feel hotter than it actually is. The heat index is usually used for afternoon high temperatures.
Docs.returns: The heat index, also known as the apparent temperature

Docs.summary: The heat index (or apparent temperature) is used to measure the amount of discomfort during the summer months when heat and humidity often combine to make it feel hotter than it actually is. The heat index is usually used for afternoon high temperatures.
Docs.returns: The heat index, also known as the apparent temperature

MemberSignature.Value: public static UnitsNet.Ratio GetRelativeHumidityFromActualAirTemperature (UnitsNet.Temperature airTemperatureFromHumiditySensor, UnitsNet.Ratio relativeHumidityMeasured, UnitsNet.Temperature airTemperatureFromBetterPlacedSensor);

.method public static hidebysig valuetype UnitsNet.Ratio GetRelativeHumidityFromActualAirTemperature(valuetype UnitsNet.Temperature airTemperatureFromHumiditySensor, valuetype UnitsNet.Ratio relativeHumidityMeasured, valuetype UnitsNet.Temperature airTemperatureFromBetterPlacedSensor) cil managed

Public Shared Function GetRelativeHumidityFromActualAirTemperature (airTemperatureFromHumiditySensor As Temperature, relativeHumidityMeasured As Ratio, airTemperatureFromBetterPlacedSensor As Temperature) As Ratio
static member GetRelativeHumidityFromActualAirTemperature : UnitsNet.Temperature * UnitsNet.Ratio * UnitsNet.Temperature -> UnitsNet.Ratio

Docs.param: Temperature measured by the humidity sensor
Humidity measured
Temperature measured by better placed sensor
Docs.summary: Calculates a corrected relative humidity. This is useful if you have a temperature/humidity sensor that is placed in a location where the temperature is different from the real ambient temperature (like it sits inside a hot case) and another temperature-only sensor that gives more reasonable ambient temperature readings. Do note that the relative humidity is dependent on the temperature, because it depends on how much water a volume of air can contain, which increases with temperature.
Docs.returns: A corrected humidity. The value will be lower than the input value if the better placed sensor is cooler than the "bad" sensor.

Public Shared Function GetRelativeHumidityFromActualAirTemperature (airTemperatureFromHumiditySensor As Temperature, relativeHumidityMeasured As RelativeHumidity, airTemperatureFromBetterPlacedSensor As Temperature) As RelativeHumidity
static member GetRelativeHumidityFromActualAirTemperature : UnitsNet.Temperature * UnitsNet.RelativeHumidity * UnitsNet.Temperature -> UnitsNet.RelativeHumidity

Docs.param: Temperature measured by the humidity sensor

Temperature measured by better placed sensor
Docs.summary: Calculates a corrected relative humidity. This is useful if you have a temperature/humidity sensor that is placed in a location where the temperature is different from the real ambient temperature (like it sits inside a hot case) and another temperature-only sensor that gives more reasonable ambient temperature readings. Do note that the relative humidity is dependent on the temperature, because it depends on how much water a volume of air can contain, which increases with temperature.
Docs.returns: A corrected humidity. The value will be lower than the input value if the better placed sensor is cooler than the "bad" sensor.

Docs.summary: The mean sea-level pressure (MSLP) is the average atmospheric pressure at mean sea level
